title: Migrant integration cockpits and dashboards
abstract: In ""MICADO: Migrant Integration Cockpits and Dashboards"", experts from public administration, migration research, and IT create an EU-wide applicable business intelligence solution in support of migrant integration, and pilot it in Antwerp, Bologna, Hamburg, and Madrid. The solution leverages existing and new data to design attractive digital services for three user groups: 1) public authorities for labour, health, education and housing, 2) engaged civic society, and 3) migrants and refugees. Added value is generated by a) delivery of customized information and services via user-centric interfaces (dashboards, cockpits); b) gathering of data consensually provided by migrants and helpers in their cockpits; c) creation of strategic operational knowledge through data analysis and visualisation; and d) direct communication and data exchange between involved stakeholders and institutions. Key technical innovations are chatbot language interfaces and automatic translation services for the migrants' cockpit, which facilitate access to integration services, communication with authorities, and data acquisition. Besides the technical solution, MICADO creates in local co-design sessions a universal service package, e.g. location and activity mapping, personal profiling, or matchmaking for mentors, jobs, education, etc. The workplan ensures extensive demand analysis and co-creation with user groups in the pilot locations. This identifies common challenges for the concept convergence phase, which produces the requirements for technical design and development. A resulting “universal” MICADO solution has monitored pilot implementations in the four cities, results of which are fed back into final iterations of technical development of the project partners. In the final project phase, co-development activities with local communities and institutions ensure uptake and local adaptation of the basic MICADO solution, and initiate context-specific modifications.

motivations: Migrant integration is a complex issue that requires effective data-driven solutions to support public authorities, civic society, and migrants themselves.
Existing migrant integration efforts often lack customized information and services, hindering the ability of stakeholders to make informed decisions.
objectives: Design and pilot an EU-wide applicable business intelligence solution to support migrant integration.
Develop user-centric interfaces (dashboards, cockpits) that deliver customized information and services to public authorities, civic society, and migrants.
Create strategic operational knowledge through data analysis and visualization to facilitate migrant integration.
methods: Leverage existing and new data to design digital services for migrant integration.
Implement chatbot language interfaces and automatic translation services to facilitate access to integration services and data acquisition.
Conduct co-design sessions with local stakeholders to create a universal service package for migrant integration.
results: Enhance migrant integration through data-driven decision-making and customized services.
Improve communication and data exchange between stakeholders and institutions involved in migrant integration.
Develop a scalable and adaptable solution for migrant integration that can be applied across the EU.

motivations: Migrant integration faces challenges due to fragmented information and services across different authorities and organizations.
There is a lack of effective digital tools that facilitate communication and data exchange between migrants, public authorities, and civic society.
Existing integration services are not easily accessible to migrants due to language barriers and complex administrative processes.
objectives: Create an EU-wide business intelligence solution that supports migrant integration through customized digital services for public authorities, civic society, and migrants.
Develop user-centric interfaces including dashboards and cockpits that facilitate access to integration services and enable direct communication between stakeholders.
Design and implement a universal service package that can be adapted to local contexts while addressing common integration challenges.
methods: Conduct co-design sessions with user groups in pilot cities to identify requirements and create a universal service package.
Develop technical innovations including chatbot language interfaces and automatic translation services to improve accessibility.
Implement iterative development through pilot implementations in four cities with continuous feedback integration.
results: Improved access to integration services for migrants through user-friendly digital interfaces and multilingual support.
Enhanced coordination and data exchange between public authorities, civic society, and migrants leading to more effective integration processes.
Creation of a scalable and adaptable solution that can be implemented across different European cities with local customizations.
